perturbation.original_text: MEMBERSHIP. The person(s) named as the Insured(s) or the Annuitant(s) is a benefit member of the Society. Rights and privileges of membership are set forth in the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws of the Society. These rights and privileges are separate from the ownership of this contract.
perturbation.changed_text: MEMBERSHIP. The person(s) named as the Insured(s) or the Annuitant(s) is a benefit member of the Society. Rights and privileges of membership are set forth in the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws of the Society. These rights and privileges are inherently linked to the ownership of this contract.
perturbation.explanation: By stating that membership rights are 'inherently linked' to the contract's ownership, it contradicts the earlier statement that they are 'separate.' This introduces ambiguity regarding the member's rights, potentially conflicting with established fraternal benefit society regulations that carefully delineate membership benefits from contractual benefits.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Fraternal Benefit Society Regulations - specifically those pertaining to membership rights versus contractual obligations in insurance contracts.

perturbation.original_text: DIVIDENDS. Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is not expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.changed_text: DIVIDENDS. Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, as we see fit, will be credited as a dividend. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is not expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'if any' to 'as we see fit' gives the company discretionary power over dividend allocation, contradicting the implied fairness in 'divisible surplus' distribution. This creates uncertainty, especially since the contract states dividends are not expected, yet provides for the possibility. It could conflict with regulations requiring equitable treatment of policyholders in mutual or fraternal benefit societies.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Insurance regulations related to equitable distribution of divisible surplus among policyholders in mutual or fraternal benefit societies.

perturbation.original_text: ASSIGNMENT The ASSIGNMENT section is amended to include the following: You may transfer ownership of this contract in accordance with our bylaws. Society membership rights and privileges cannot be transferred or assigned.
perturbation.changed_text: ASSIGNMENT The ASSIGNMENT section is amended to include the following: You may transfer ownership of this contract; however, transfer of such ownership includes an assumption of all rights and responsibilities as the original owner. Society membership rights and privileges are automatically transferred with contract ownership.
perturbation.explanation: Contradicts itself by first stating that membership rights can't be transferred or assigned, then saying that membership rights are automatically transferred with contract ownership, creating uncertainty about what will happen to the membership status of the society. Also it contradicts the definition of rights and priviliges in MEMBERSHIP
perturbation.contradicted_law: Insurance regulations about who can be a member and the status of being a member of a society.
